children.value: in each step according to the following rule
w_{t+1} = w_t - \alpha_t \cdot \nabla f(w_t) = w_t - \alpha_t \cdot \frac{1}{n} \sum_{x \in \mathcal{D}} \nabla f(w; x)

children.value: is the Hessian matrix, which is the second order derivatives matrix. Sometimes people directly write

children.value: memory. Despite the problem with existence of second order derivative, the enormous extra time we have to spend calculating Hessian matrix when

children.html: ddd

children.value: gets big is the main reason why people avoid Newton’s method.
We can prove that gradient descent works under the assumption that the second derivative of the objective is bounded. Formally, such function is called

children.html: ∥∇f(w)−∇f(u)∥2≤L∥u−v∥2\| \nabla f(w) - \nabla f(u) \|_2 \le L \| u-v \|_2∥∇f(w)−∇f(u)∥2​≤L∥u−v∥2​

children.value: From the above definition, we can derive the following property, which guarantees that
small change in weight only results in small change in gradient
(the rate of gradient change is bounded by

children.html: LLL

children.value: ) This is the intuition behind why we need L-smooth for GD to converge.
\forall \mathbf w,\mathbf u \in \R^d, \alpha \in \R \; s.t. \|\mathbf u\|=1, \; \|\frac{\partial^2}{\partial\alpha^2} f(\mathbf w+\alpha \mathbf u) \| \le L
children.html: ∀w,u∈Rd,α∈R  s.t.∥u∥=1,  ∥∂2∂α2f(w+αu)∥≤L\forall \mathbf w,\mathbf u \in \R^d, \alpha \in \R \; s.t. \|\mathbf u\|=1, \; \|\frac{\partial^2}{\partial\alpha^2} f(\mathbf w+\alpha \mathbf u) \| \le L∀w,u∈Rd,α∈Rs.t.∥u∥=1,∥∂α2∂2​f(w+αu)∥≤L

children.value: and a small x change can result in arbitrary large gradient descent, so this is bad for gradient descent.

children.value: , though we do not know whether that is a local minimum or a global one. No matter what kind of a minimum it is, if we reach it, we can call Gradient Descent has converged. Therefore, we want to make the bound on the right as tight as possible.
We can do this by either running more iterations

children.html: TTT

children.value: or have a faster learning rate
